title: To Riot Games  : What about doing your job like your predecessors ?
body:
This applies to every champion and not only about irelia.

http://www.mypokecard.com/my/galery/gv0E07tldcJr.jpg

https://static.fjcdn.com/pictures/Morello+nerf+everything+got+off+wwwleaguememecom_ff34ff_3939365.jpg

if you buff too much a champion and he is OP 50% only will complain the 5 on 10 players on the opponent team.

10% of the players complaining is better than 50% of them.

#**Banrates have nothing to do with balance**

Show winrate, playrate, and winrate range based on number of games played. Don't just go "hurr durr their banrate is high so they need nerfs". As an example based on content in your post: Yasuo's banrate was still well above 30% when he was at a 42% winrate. He did not need nerfs because he was literally the worst champion in the game at that time, yet if we were to nerf him just because of his banrate being high it'd have gone even lower.

Ban rate does have a place though. 
If a champions game presence is high - through picks AND bans - then it indicates a problem regardless of win rate. 
Ban rate on its own only reflects how the community feels about them or in some cases the designer behind them. So you need to use it in conjunction with other stats, much like every other piece in the Pick/Win/Ban trio.

> [{quoted}](name=Paroe,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=TVlx3EH9,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2018-11-04T12:34:45.765+0000)
> Ban rate on its own only reflects how the community feels about them or in some cases the designer behind them.

This has NOTHING to do with how strong the champ *actually is.*

Banrate is the perfect indication of how a champion is accepted by the players. If the ban rate skyrockets the balance team should take a look at the champion and find out why the banrate skyrockets and bring up a solution.

Sure the banrate isn't the best indicator of how a champion is balanced but ßit is a good tool to look into why the players are unhappy.

But if the only thing that would make players "happy" is nerfing the champ into oblivion, they'll find the next champion to bitch about while the players of that champ will now be unhappy. Zoe's a good example. If she becomes even relatively relevant again, we'll never hear the end of it, even if there's tons of in-game ways to deal with her yourself.

This is then the devs job to find the spot that the champion is in an ok state. If the problem isn't the numbers that the champion is to strong that makes the players unhappy then the devs have to find a rework to make it work.

But the champs people hate aren't always too strong. Yasuo is rarely ever *too strong* in comparison to how much people perma-ban and despise him, for example. You guys just say he is, and when you're proven wrong you go to the stupid "unfun" argument.

No, just read it again. If the ban rate is high but the problem isn't any numbers in his kit it is the kit itself and so the devs have to find a solution for the problem.
It isn't allways that a champion is to strong, but when the banrates are that high it shows that the playerbase dislikes the champion and the devs should look for a solution.

That has nothing to do with balance, though. Also, once again, we'll just go on forever with one champ or another being perma-banned and permanently altered because people can't accept that champs need to do different things.
It will then go in a cycle and every champion will be targeted at one point which leads to a more balanced game. Nerfing is healthier then buffing.
This is a massive 180 from the days where everyone was crying for *buffs* instead of nerfs. What makes you think we won't just 180 again?

We already had a time where there were nerfs instead of buffs. And riot changed it to buffs instead of nerfs and look where we are right now. A game with no strategic decisions and nearly no skill included anymore. The only decision you have to make is "will i do my all in now or after i last hit the next minion".
Well, no, but sure, you can type that sentence.
When there's over 140 champions and the same ~10 are getting banned every game, it's a balance problem.

Did you perhaps consider it's a perception problem?

People perceive them as too strong because they got their ass completely and utterly stomped by one. Because we've all had at least one game where a Yasuo single-handedly carried his entire team to victory. People tend to remember Yasuo going 30/2/18. Or the Irelia that went 15/0 in lane because top lost lane but jg and mid didn't bother to respond until it was *way* too late. Or the Kassadin who was 8/1 before level 11 so he was just able to roll over the enemy team.

They *don't* tend to remember the 80 times before when said champion was mediocre or useless. They don't remember the Yasuo being only 1/2/4 and only really existing to protect his team with his W, or the Irelia who was only really useful for her CC on E and R. Or the Kassadin who went 0/4 in lane and remained useless for the entire game.

And, as I said, they usually have huge banrates whether or not they're strong (except for Kassadin, who only has a high banrate when actually meta). So it's often *not* a balance problem, but rather a mix of confirmation bias and just not wanting to learn to deal with the champion.

Everyone who knows how to actually fight Yasuo doesn't ban him, unless he's actually a counter to them, or it's a target ban.
Weird way to say *perception* problem.
To be fair though Yasuo is gonna have a high banrate until he gets reworked. His kit probably tilts more players than anyone else.

I would rather say the main reason why champs being OP as they are is because of circumstance. Meaning that they are where they at is because everybody got nerfed to the ground to the point where they no longer feel good to play. When you look at seasons past and compare champions with their past versions, you can clearly see they are no where near as strong as they were before. Kassadin and Leblanc for example, their season 3 selves would absolutely destroy their current iterations.

The way the game is today is completely derived from nerfing everybody instead of buffing those who have been underperforming. Not saying there isnt any champs that needs a touch of nerf but more often than not the said nerfs almost always hit the wrong places. Gnar being a literal gatekeeper of top lane for many years? Nerf everything except the one that makes him unbearable which would be his %max HP proc.

I personally like nerfs. Nami was recently nerfed. I love that lil fish. I had to learn how to adapt and play a little safer and it's been FUN. railing through a game because your champion is broken isn't fun, it's just exploitative.

Mobility, durability, utility, damage. Those things are crammed more and more into kits to make "interesting" and "exciting" new champions. And nothing is sacrificed to gain an excess of one or 3 of these. Look at malphite. Look at renekton. Look at ashe. They have SOME of these as very strong in their kit, but other things they are weak at. They are exploitable, but good at what they are meant to be good at. Their power curves are more balanced... having a point where they are stronger than average, a point where they are average, and a point where they are weaker (not necessarily in that order). They require items to emphasize these strengths and/or make up for innate weaknesses. Ex: You want to be tanky on renekton? You need to BUILD tanky - no free 70% dmg reduction spammable spell or shield. You want to do damage? You need to BUILD damage. No insane overtuned base stats, no double your crit chance... just average or even below average bruiser level base stats without over-the-top scalings too. You stack armor on malphite because his kit makes extra good use of it? You still have to build mr or you are toast. And your basic abilities are largely mediocre at best - a tradeoff for having such a powerful ult.

This kind of balance and logic has been forgotten or ignored when designing new champs and items in favor of non-stop hype.
